description: {"blocks":[{"key":"enl9q","text":"Protocol to precipitate extracted DNA from an aqueous solution to increase concentration or resolubilize in a different storage buffer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fdrgg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4oi1","text":"*Use isopropanol DNA precipitation if your DNA is suspended in a very large volume, if your DNA concentration is low, or you are trying to concentrate large molecular weight DNA fragments and remove smaller fragments.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"34hc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"roit","text":"*Use ethanol DNA precipitation if you are trying to remove salt contamination or precipitate small DNA fragments.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3neiq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37br9","text":"Additional Resources:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"faoc9","text":"New England Biolabs, \"DNA Precipitation: Ethanol vs. Isopropanol\". June 23, 2015","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":80}],"data":{}},{"key":"a1ol2","text":"Green, Michael R. and Joseph Sambrook, \"Precipitation of DNA with Isopropanol\". doi:10.1101/pdb.prot093385Cold Spring Harb Protoc2017.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":134}],"data":{}},{"key":"a2s8d","text":"Qiagen, \"How can I precipitate genomic DNA using isopropanol?\".","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":63}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"D525FF10007A11EC99E15BE085F374D1","url":"https://bitesizebio.com/2839/dna-precipitation-ethanol-vs-isopropanol/"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"00933EB0007B11EC99E15BE085F374D1","url":"http://cshprotocols.cshlp.org/content/2017/8/pdb.prot093385.full"}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"43748590007B11EC99E15BE085F374D1","url":"https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/faq?id=5cf3006a-c63f-48d6-89d9-9ae14329c230\u0026lang=en"}}}}

funders.funder_name: Realizing Increased Photosynthetic Efficiency (RIPE) that is funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Foundation for Food and Agriculture Research, and the U.K. Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office

guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"1h6du","text":"DNA precipitation performed at room temperature minimizes co-precipitation of salt that interferes with downstream applications.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
keywords: DNA Precipitation, DNA, Isopropanol, DNA Concentration
materials_text: {"blocks":[{"key":"2hnc7","text":"Reagents:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"agdq2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80e3r","text":"Isopropanol, room temperature","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"496nu","text":"70% Ethanol, ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3j6if","text":" *Measure 70 ml of ethanol and 30 ml of distilled water separately and then mix.Do not measure 70 ml of ethanol and then bring to volume.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6e3hf","text":" NOTE: 70% ethanol is hygroscopic. When opened the ethanol will both evaporate and absorb water over time. Re-use eventually will be at a lower concentration. There is also miscibility of ethanol and water. For example, measuring out 70 mL of ethanol and topping off to 100 mL with water will generate ~65% ethanol. Measuring 70 mL ethanol and 30 mL water separately, then combining them will generate ~95 mL of 70% ethanol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":24,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"db1is","text":"Sodium acetate (3 M, pH 5.2): 0.246g/mL (0.738g/3mL dH2O)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8s9s6","text":" DNA resuspension solution.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"27g9g","text":" *Molecular Grade Water: Safest option for downstream applications.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":41,"length":42}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5un2q","text":" *TE buffer (pH 8.0), 100 mL: Allows easier resuspension of DNA pellet. Inhibits DNases. Good for long term storage but may interfere with enzymes in downstream applications.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":47,"length":144}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"91q41","text":" Reagent Volume Final concentration 1M Tris-Cl (pH 8.0) 1 mL 10 mM 0.5M EDTA (pH 8.0) 0.02 mL (20 ul) 0.1 mM Distilled H2O 99 mL ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":223}],"data":{}},{"key":"4sevc","text":" 1)Mix all components. Autoclave to sterilize.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9esf6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7nurb","text":" A) 1 M Tris-Cl (pH 8.0), 10 mL","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"83a6s","text":" Reagent Volume Final concentration Tris base 1.21 g 10 M Distilled H2O 10  mL ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":144}],"data":{}},{"key":"ah00u","text":" i) Weigh out 1.21 g Tris and add to a 15 mL centrifuge tube.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"29gem","text":" ii) Measure out 8 mL of distilled water and add to the tube.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"25l85","text":" iii) Stir to mix the solution.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7qsra","text":" iv) Add a pH meter into the solution to observe the pH.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8otu5","text":" v) Slowly add concentrated hydrochloric acid (HCl) solution using a Pasteur pipette to reduce the pH to 8.0, or another desired pH. Be careful not to add too much at a time, since the pH will change rapidly.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eilbc","text":" vi) Once the desired pH has been reached, top up the solution to 10 mL using distilled water.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bmss7","text":" B) 0.5M EDTA pH 8.0, 5 mL","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edbdp","text":" Reagent Volume Final concentration EDTA disodium salt, dihydrate 0.93 g 0.5 M Distilled H2O 5 mL ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":163}],"data":{}},{"key":"3u74v","text":" i) Weigh out 0.93 g EDTA disodium salt, dihydrate and add to a centrifuge tube.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e0mbj","text":" ii) Measure out 3.5 mL distilled water and add to the tube.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cpbje","text":" iii) Shake to mix. The EDTA salt will not go into solution until the pH reaches 8.0.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5n9tc","text":" iv) Add a pH meter into the solution to observe the pH.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dpkf0","text":" v) To dissolve the salt, add sodium hydroxide (NaOH) pellets to the solution. Add a few pellets at a time and wait until the pellets have fully dissolved before adding more. It may take around 0.1 g of NaOH pellets before the pH is at 8.0.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aqeo0","text":" vi) Once fully dissolved (this will take some time so be patient), top up the solution to 1 mL using distilled water, if necessary.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"er3kp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4008u","text":"Materials:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"erm35","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h179","text":"Analytical balance","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"39v0a","text":"pH meter","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"69lb2","text":"Graduated cylinder","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45bii","text":"Pipette, single channel, 1-100 ul","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ecttk","text":"Pipette tips, 1-100 ul","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"133rd","text":"1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9n0dq","text":"Microcentrifuge","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4r2iv","text":"Paper towel or kim wipe","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fcuvq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1fdj2","text":" status.info: We use this protocol and it’s working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2tn5t","text":"Transfer desired amount of aqueous DNA solution to a fresh microtube. (70 ul)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b7btm","text":"Add 3.0 M pH 5.2 sodium acetate to the DNA solution to result in a final concentration of 0.3 M sodium acetate. (7 ul)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f0qdv","text":"Add 0.6–0.7 volume of isopropanol at room temperature and mix well. (50 ul)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fd8e9","text":"Point caps of tubes out to help identify pellet location below cap. Centrifuge the sample immediately at 10,000–15,000 x g for 20–30 min in a microcentrifuge tube at 4°C.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"90ot8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cg83l","text":"Identify the pelleted DNA. Carefully decant the supernatant fluid into a fresh labeled tube without losing the pellet. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ek1v7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bauqj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6j06m","text":"If concerned about losing DNA pellet during decanting, the supernatant can be stored in a fresh tube until the recovery of the precipitated DNA is confirmed.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"103g2","text":"Wash the DNA pellet by adding 500 ul or more (depending on the size of the preparation) of room-temperature 70% ethanol. Flick tube and invert several times until pellet is removed from the side of the tube and all sides can be washed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ksbo","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cf8it","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7i2es","text":"Thorough 70% ethanol washing is critical to remove residual isopropanol which can hinder the redissolution of the DNA.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"57ahs","text":"Centrifuge the sample at 10,000–15,000 x g for 20–30 min at 4°C.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4i8bp","text":"Visually identify the pellet. Pour out ethanol.  Tap tube gently on paper towel, being sure to keep track of the pellet.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f819e","text":"Optional: For high quality DNA applications requiring very clean DNA extractions, repeat steps 6-8. More ethanol washes will increase quality but will negatively affect recovery.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8fph0","text":"After last ethanol wash, use a pipette to remove any ethanol that remains after decanting.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bbj3h","text":" Allow samples to air dry at room temperature for 10-20 min. When pellet turns from white to clear the pellet is dry.  Do not over dry.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f938l","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9rmm9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f99br","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"asp1i","text":"Overdrying of the pellet will make resuspension of the DNA more difficult.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4tbs4","text":"Resuspend the DNA pellet in Tris, TE (pH 8.0), or molecular grade water.  Incubate in   overnight for more complete resuspension.  For long term storage, store at  .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":86,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":163,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6dbm2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"A2B8E120007D11EC8D5B6540D520041B","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"E3C29130643B11ECACC1CF4E3F74940D","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"-20","unit":10}}}}
